original_data.question: A 42-year-old woman presents to her obstetrician for a prenatal care appointment at 10 weeks gestation. The patient recently found out she was pregnant after having unprotected intercourse with her husband for the past year. She states that she is feeling well and has experienced some nausea and vomiting. She is currently taking prenatal vitamins and folate supplements. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, you notice a gravid uterus 10 cm above the pubic symphysis. The patient's external genitalia appear within normal limits. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

model_response:
The patient's age and the duration of time since her last menstrual period make her at an increased risk for having a fetus with Down syndrome. The most accurate way to diagnose Down syndrome in a fetus is through genetic testing, which can be done either through amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling. Cell-free DNA testing is a new non-invasive test that can also be used to diagnose Down syndrome, but it is not as accurate as either amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling. Chorionic villus sampling is usually performed earlier in pregnancy, between 10 and 13 weeks gestation, so it is not the best choice in this case because the patient is only 10 weeks gestation. Regular follow-up appointments and ultrasounds are not as accurate as genetic testing in diagnosing Down syndrome.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Qualified medical professionals who specialize in OBSTETRICS.
Care provided the pregnant woman in order to prevent complications, and decrease the incidence of maternal and prenatal mortality.
A meeting arranged with someone at a particular time and place.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Observed to be or have been pregnant.
Sexual intercourse without the use of precautions to prevent conception or the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases.
The sexual union of a male and a female, a term used for human only.
A male partner in marriage.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
A constituent administrative district of a nation.

An unpleasant sensation in the stomach usually accompanied by the urge to vomit. Common causes are early pregnancy, sea and motion sickness, emotional stress, intense pain, food poisoning, and various enteroviruses.
The forcible expulsion of the contents of the STOMACH through the MOUTH.
A vitamin enriched supplement containing higher doses for specific nutrients such as folic acid, intended for women before, during and after pregnancy and also during their lactating phase.
Providing folate based on suboptimal food or fluid intake, iatrogenic deficiency or medical diagnosis.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
Unmodified air as existing in the immediate surroundings.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A bone that forms the lower and anterior part of each side of the hip bone.
A form of articulation in which the bones are connected by intervening substance admitting slight motion.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
The external genitalia of the female. It includes the CLITORIS, the labia, the vestibule, and its glands.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
